content.body: just waiting on html4diffs and h:tml to be updated now
othermaciej: I just now updated the h:tml draft and waiting for the cvs commit to complete
oK
done
MikeSmith: hawt
MikeSmith: so now we're just waiting on Anne
OK
annevk still awake?
I asked him to update earlier today, so hopefully he'll do it whenever he gets up
I am assuming no
I asked him to update ~5 hours ago
even though it is an arbitrary milestone, I am for some reason very excited about publishing
othermaciej: I think the biggest positive effect of WD publication is that it gets documents a lot wider attention than just editor's-draft publication does
at least as far as W3C publication goes
and for a certain period of time, at least
in the context of HTML5, I have not seen it result in a higher level of technical review
yeah
though it does get some sort of attention in the tech press
othermaciej: yeah, the downside of that is that one of the first questions all the media people seem to ask every time W3C publishes and HTML5 WD is that, "OK, so when will HTML5 be done?" question
to which it seems to me the only proper response is to try to get them to see that they're asking the wrong question
but that's not usually successfull
then we can just point to the charter and indicate that the next milestone is Last Call
which is on schedule, so long as we can invent time travel technology in the next few months
heh
the ietf guys argued that websocket would get wider review if we went through the ietf, but so far all the useful feedback i've received has been either off-list or on the whatwg list
similar to how it was argued that html5 would get more review if we went through the w3c
looks to me like the standards organisations are out of date in terms of what gets wider useful feedback :-)
Hixie: I sent useful feedback on the ietf list... I think
i think everything you said on the list you first said on the adam/you/me thread we had
and adam and you would have reviewed the spec anyway, regardless of whether we went w3c, whatwg, or ietf
nah, I pointed out the reverse cross-protocol problem on the list first, then discussed it with you on IRC, then on the email thread with Adam
I would like to say I would have given that feedback anyway but I only thought of it due to people questioning the handshake
fair enough

Hixie: standards organizations are out of date in a lot of ways.. I guess until we actually work on coming up with viable alternative, we are stuck with what we got, and hopefully at least we can (or have) managed to get some improvements made
I mean, I might have still had the thought
MikeSmith: my most successful standard i think has been pingback, which didn't involve a standards organisation at all
it's not clear to me how to make a good standards org
MikeSmith: so it's not clear to me that we _need_ an alternative
I think the existence of the Web Sockets discussion at IETF has helped to changed the IETF culture for the better
all the existing ones either come down to pay-to-play voting or dictatorship by an elite oligarchy, if you push hard enough
really? how so?
er, that was to mike
othermaciej: i think the oligarchy mechanism is the only one that truly works, but it only works so long as the oligarchy has the respect of the implementors
othermaciej: and i think it pretty much stops having the respect as soon as there's a process in place, because a process forcibly distances the oligarchy from the implementors
part of the problem the w3c and ietf both have is that they try to solve too many problems at once
having multiple focus areas is a huge red flag for a std org imho
Hixie: I think the implementors issue is something that the Web Sockets work has helped to raise awareness about in the IETF
oligarchy can work with the right oligarchs
and so long as it does not get overwhelmed with legitimacy disputes
legitimacy disputes = lack of respect
Hixie: the awareness being that it is risky to develop a spec without also working hard to get implementor buy-in during the spec-development process
IETF and W3C try to have consensus/voting as the front line decision-making tool, with escalation to a dictator/oligarchy
sometimes I wonder if the other way around would work better
of course, in the HTML WG we kinda have a sandwich
not really
we just have three tiers of <span>abort the
er
mispaste
we just have three tiers of oligarchy
I guess layers at least limit the damage that can be done by any one layer going off the rails
each tier being further removed from the issues, leading to more and more random resolutions as an issue is escalated ;-)
I find I need to have a lot more familiarity with the issues than I think I should have to for my role
wonders what Apple's Webkit devs are doing
right now?
most of them are either at home, or having dinner
roc: i think he means his role as htmlwg chair, not webkit manager :-P
oh
yeah
no, my comment was random
heh
trac would give you a good approximation if you can filter down to Apple committers
indeed
webkit devs seem to be doing a lot of bug fixing these days, as opposed to feature implementation
MikeSmith clearly reads the webkit commits twitter feed
I do notice that Dirk Schulze seems to still be actively been doing some refinements to the svg filters stuff
I wish trac had a better way to track commits per-developer
per-committer feeds
i wish trac had a lot of things
Hixie: who's developed the http://html5.org/tools/web-apps-tracker UI, annevk ?
yes
iirc
at last he hosts it
OK
it's in google code if you want to offer patches
product html5, iirc
OK
I would like for it to have a feature that lets users supplement that indicators
man, the per-platform test results make Webkit SVN enormous
ok, bbl, food time.
if anyone wants to review proposals for websocket, i just regenned the complete.html spec with the new proposed handshake

Hixie: (when you get back) - I'm wondering if you made any changes at all in response to Noah's message about explicitly defining the term "conforming document" - http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-comments/2010Feb/0011.html
othermaciej: I think at some point we should publish a WD of the static "author view" of HTML5
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec-author-view/
MikeSmith: I agree
MikeSmith: should it still have all the trappings of normativity?
that part I dunno
I feel weird having multiple normative references for the same thing even if they are mechanically generated from a single source
but other than that - we did suggest to the TAG that we'd like to do this
and that TAG seems to actually like that doc OK
Noah at least does, I know
well, I guess I shouldn't say "I know", but I think he has publicly commented quite positively
anyway, I suppose we should start discussion about publishing after we get the current round of WDs out
*publishing the author view
yeah I'd like to get the current round done
and get more issues in the pipeline
we have 10 sitting on "Chairs" now
othermaciej: I also have a couple of bugzilla bugs assigned to me that have not been escalated to issues yet and that I'm hoping won't have to be
hmm, http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-bugzilla/2010Mar/0008.html
"Can the script element please allow the scope attribute in the same semantic way as the style element? The dom would be limited to only elements under that node."
interesting idea
hard to implement and use
probably not viable as as a security feature, if that is what the commentor intends
not sure what the commenter intends -- the embedded commenting feature is great for reporting outright bugs but doesn't encourage a lot of elaboration
Hixie: so your most successful spec depends on xml-rpc!
hsivonen: which one is that?
MikeSmith: i don't think so... did he file a bug?
Hixie: no, he didn't.. I can suggest to him that he should, or I can file one myself, I guess. He just posted only to the public-html-comments list about it, as far as I can see
goes to raise new bug for it
MikeSmith: pingback according to the log
ah
hsivonen: yeah, that's embarassing as heck :-)
MikeSmith, I'll update nowish I guess
is trying to wake up
annevk: great
has a headache for unknown reasons
wonders if it's because the heating is working again and his body is no longer used to the warmth
Hixie: http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9178 (new bug for defining "conforming document")
btw, I notice that pubrules still doesn't recognize CSS3 color names
I would say, "That seems like it would be relatively easy to fix" but if I did I would probably get asked to fix it
othermaciej: I guess one advantage of publishing the author view of the spec as non-normative would be that we'd not need to do an LC round for it
nor CR
MikeSmith: we'd probably want to anyway, to let it stay in sync with the main HTML5 draft
yeah, true
no, not true
MikeSmith: how hard do you think it would be to get pubrules changed to allow HTML5 as a publication format?
I periodically have the urge to try to pursue that, but I am not sure if it is worth my time
pubrules would be relatively easy to change, actually
it's not a technical problem that blocks that
I didn't mean "how technically hard"
well, not hard, then
I mean, "If I suggested it, is there a chance I'd get anywhere?"
I meant, "well, hard, then"
and if so, what would be the right venue
should I ask privately what the actual blocker is?
no need to ask privately
what's the actual blocker?
I wondered if maybe there was some idea that a format spec had to be at REC before it could be used, but I notices that even Working Drafts of XHTML1 were published as XHTML1, not as HTML4
the blocker is that the team doesn't believe it's appropriate yet to be publishing documents that use features from HTML5 that are not at least in a PR draft
so it doesn't seem like there is a hard and fast rule
as far as XHTML1 and HTML4, that was then, this is now
there were a whole lot of corners cut in publishing HTML4 and XHTML1
I would suggest that we don't want to use their publication approach as a precedent
it just seems like an embarrassment to me that we can't publish HTML5 as HTML5
but from what you say, it sounds like it would be a waste of time to pursue it
it's an embarassment to the w3c
html5 has been published as html5 for years
fwiw, I have argued that simply using <!doctype html> as the doctype on a document does not constitute publishing it as HTML5
it's an embarrassment to the HTML WG, even though it is not up to us
anyway I'll mentally file it away as "it's political and not worth pursuing" unless the other HTML WG chairs decide they care too at some point
I am happy to pursue it if the chairs will agree to support pushing for it
I'll ask the other co-chairs then
another data point: XHTML 1.1 Working Drafts were also published as XHTML 1.1
that's not quite as long ago as HTML4 or XHTML 1.0, but still pretty long ago
XHTML 1.1 is another case of a spec that I don't think it'd be prudent to use as a precedent for anything
anyway, I don't want to (re)raise it if somebody's going to end up pulling the rug out from underneath
I'm not asking you to pursue it right now
I just wanted to understand the issue
OK
I do want to say that a technical way we could address this is in part is by having <!doctype html> be defined in a separate spec that we could move through Rec track more quickly
this is the relevant rule, right: http://www.w3.org/2005/07/pubrules?uimode=filter&uri=#format
othermaciej: yeah
interesting note: the XHTML 1.1 REC is in violation of that rule
yep
anyway, to be clear, I do think it is worth pursuing at least getting agreement to be allowed to publish the spec with the <!doctype html> doctype
but I suggest that not be considered the same thing as "publishing
othermaciej: occasionally, I wish people who raise process issues about the HTML WG went raise the same issues about the XHTML2 WG first
the most recent violation of pubrules format requirements I can find so far was January 16, 2009
MikeSmith, I doubt that would go to REC more quicly
meant to write, I suggest that not be considered the same thing as publishing the spec "as HTML5"
annevk: why?
MikeSmith, because there's a bunch of open debates around the DOCTYPE
(I also have no idea how you would separate it out, but aside from that...)
to be fair this is only a Note, perhaps those are not considered to have any normative versions at all
http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/NOTE-xhtml-media-types-20090116/
hsivonen: it does seem that the HTML WG gets singled for process problems that are not unique to this group
but the pubrules for WG Notes still have the format requirements
this one seems to have slipped through the checker
if the doctype were a separate spec, versioning fans could object to it and say in public that they aren't objecting to HTML5--just the doctype
othermaciej: I'm not sure whether the pubrules checker has always checked for the doctype constraint or not
I think mi
it might just pass it to the validator as-is
hsivonen: I suppose
I do fear that splitting off the doctype could harm substantive progress
Is role="banner" gone?
so the thing is, we would then need to define what we mean by "publishing as HTML5"
JonathanNeal: it still exists - just not default
I couldn't find it anywhere in the draft.
for example, does "publishing as HTML5" mean we want it to be OK for a document to include features that don't yet have any implementation support?
JonathanNeal: it's specified in WAI-ARIA, which is a reference
or the WAI ARIA @ http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/#banner (seems to have been removed?)
JonathanNeal: ARIA changed to publishing only the TOC at the main URL
JonathanNeal: http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/roles#banner
it's a multipage spec
Thanks hsivonen and othermaciej, found it now.
doesn't like multipage specs
agrees with hsivonen on that one.
MikeSmith: I think we would want to exercise judgment and not use markup features that break in current browsers or that are expected to break (or change) in the future
MikeSmith: perhaps the WC3 Team would not trust the HTML WG to exercise that level of judgment
I like my find in page, so me three
A lot of these roles are now elements in HTMl5.
MikeSmith, what does publishing as HTML4 mean?
MikeSmith, we could publish HTML4 that validates perfectly fine but is not usable in any browser, is that more acceptable than HTML5?
I'd argue that with HTML5 such a problem is less likely to occur
annevk: you could write validating HTML5 that is not usable in any browser (for example if it makes assumptions about default rendering)
annevk: you're preaching to the choir here -- I'm saying we need to make sure we be clear about what it is we want to get approval for
I will ask the other two co-chairs if they feel this is an important issue
to me it's lower on the priority list than getting to Last Call, but it does kinda bother me
othermaciej: as far as trust, it would seem to me at least that the W3C Team does trust that chairs of the HTML WG
otherwise they would not continue to be the chairs
all trust has limits, I don't think they would give me the W3C's bank account number
then again, nor do I want it
i wouldn't mind if someone gave it to me
sicking: !
as long as I got permission to use it for whatever i wanted :)
hey Mike!
long time no see
yeah, i think my irc client wasn't configured to autoconnect here for a long time
iirc as a result of my mac dying
looks at maciej
though really it was seagates fault, it was due to hard drive failure
some might argue that hard drive failures are inevitable, so that any unforeseen consequences of a hard-drive failure are actually pilot error (that is, lack of preparing for the inevitable) :)
sicking: your Mac died?
sorry to hear
MikeSmith: it is true. Our desktop admin had asked me to get backup for quite some time
why is the doctype an issue?
that's not the interesting part of html5
othermaciej: work mac. HD failed. It ended up not being a huge deal, just lost a few days worth of work
I see
othermaciej: could have been *much* worse, but i got lucky
I concur with blaming yourself and/or the drive manufacturer
now i back up religiously. I have to say that time machine rocks
my most important things are checked into repositories or on mail or web servers
it would mostly be a personal annoyance, not a work one, if my drive totally failed
for Mozilla development it's pretty easy to keep your work in Mercurial patch queues and save them to http://hg.mozilla.org/users/rocallahan_mozilla.com/ etc
sicking: just don't lose XBL2!
roc: you push your mq repository there?
XBL2 is more than a pipe dream? :)
I push some there
now that I mention it, I really should push my other big queue there too
I guess for extra safety I could post more works-in-progress to bugs.webkit,.org
as a manager I don't have the time to code anything that complicated though
anxiously scans his patch queue for anything embarrassing
hg qdel video-h264
othermaciej, MikeSmith, http://dev.w3.org/html5/html4-differences/
annevk: thanks
if you're gonna do that then I guess I should delete my ogg patch from bugs.webkit.org
heh
annevk: ah, cool
roc: dude, you're sitting there watching youtube on <video> but holding out on the rest of us?
roc: i want lolcats in HTML too!!
annevk: that's a great document
thanks!
annevk: "Web Sockets" should not be a link?
annevk: under 5.3. Changes from 12 February 2009 to 23 April 2009
annevk: "potential hostile content inline" - potentially
ah, cool.. Opera "Check for Updates" works for me now in my 10.5 alpha install and lets me install beta 1
zcorpan, potentially, really?
zcorpan, there's two separate drafts, wasn't sure what to link to
it's called "WebSocket" now btw (the specs are WebSocket API and WebSocket protocol)
i guess I can rename it
Hixie, maybe remove "The" before WebSocket API? e.g. it's also Selectors API and hardly any other spec has "The"
annevk: i'm no english expert but i'd say potentially there
zcorpan, same here, but then for potential
MikeSmith, opinions?
annevk: sorry, wasn't paying attention.. what's the particular thing you guys have been talking about?
the phrase "potential hostile content inline" in my draft
annevk: I think zcorpan is right that "potentially" would be better
because "potentially" is an adverb modifying "hostile"
whereas otherwise I suppose it might be ambiguous about meaning "potential content"
fixored
so, I guess I can start getting the drafts staged into the dated TR URLs
wonders where to find 15-year-old HTML
also wonders where to find whatever dope dbaron has been smoking
img { border:0 } is one of the few things I always use when I add images
does Opera put borders on img in links by default?
nope
which is a reason I not always use that rule anymore I think
just forget about it sometimes
I wish Opera did, so that I wouldn't accidentally make pages that look uglier than expected in Firefox
I believe zcorpan did some research at some point on this subject
we have never had it in WebKit
and I don't think we ever got a bug, internal or external, to add it
othermaciej: Mac IE 5 didn't have the border
hsivonen: yeah, but in the early days, Mozilla/Phoenix/Firebird/Firefox was most people's standard of "correct' rendering
for people who filed bugs anyway
annevk: If you ever see TMS (again), make sure to bring him stroopwafels
ok, I found a bug related to borders around images
it was that we still drew a border for <input type=image border=0> in Safari 0.6
hmm I take it back, I found a site that deliberately adds a blue border to image links:
http://news.google.com/
othermaciej: that's not the *default* blue border, though, in any browser
hsivonen: indeed
asmodai, TMS being?
TMS!~Thomaspoc
annevk: i researched image borders?
zcorpan, maybe I misremembered
i might well have, don't remember either :)
asmodai, ah
I could understand arguing they are needed for compat, I was surprised at the argument that it's actually a good default
there's a request that we report whether a websocket connection closed gracefully or not
i see two ways to do this:
1. add some state data to the 'close' event
2. add a new event
if we go with 2, does anybody have any suggestions for what the two events should be?
onclose and onerrorclose?
(onerror is going to be used for when an unexpected frame type is received)
I think I prefer 1). Having to register two different event handlers in the case that you don't care about the error seems unweildy
Are people usually going to want to perform the same processing in response to both types of closing?
Plus the state seems needed anyway if there is more than one possible type of error
k
Hixie: are there any non-fatal errors?
I would say "close" and "error" if there were two events
othermaciej: yeah, receiving a frame of an unexpected type
I also think extra info in the "close" event is good
k
it would be nice if the close event could tell you the last message known to be delivered, but that requires more than clean close I think
actually you couldn't do that in the close event anyway
you need to reconnect to find that information
can't we use a different event for a frame of an unexpected type
the error event has always been used for network errors
we can use whatever event you want
what would you like
messageerror?
done
http://isgeolocationpartofhtml5.com/ sweet
Hixie: last message *known* to be delivered - it would be a pessimistic estimate in the error case, and exact in the clean close case
Hixie: would not require reconnectin
Hixie: but it would require some form of per-message acks
othermaciej: definitely v2.
not saying this is essential, just theorizing
annevk: a lot of people would disagree with that site
Hixie: I don't know if it has to be v-anything
there is a tension in designing this protocol
on the one hand, it would be hugely valuable to have practical experience before adding a lot of stuff
on the other hand, you really don't want to accidentally lock in a flawed design prematurely
that seems like a weakness in Roy's proposed "deploy first, then standardize" model
specs have to be written while implementations grow
there's no magical solution, you just have to be careful
anyway, what should this event attribute be. event.closeError?
(boolean)
I like booleans to start with something like "has" or "is" but that's hard to do in this case
event.wasClean?
what's the opposite of a clean close
abrupt?
terminated?
why do we need an event attribute if you have error/close?
annevk: it was argued that we should have only one event
that's not really consistent with , XHR, etc.
since in most cases you won't care
well on those this event is called "load"
you can just do socket.onerror = x; socket.onclose = x;
(which isn't really especially meaningful here)
annevk: yeah but that means the simple case is harder
which is bad API design
i guess those will get img.onloadend or some such
at some point
hmm
zcorpan: how about "A void element is an element whose content model never allows it to have contents under any circumstances." ?
that would seem to exclude the <colgroup span> case
an element being void or not has nothing to do with its content model, in theory
Hixie: so what does it have to do with?
(though of course in practice there's a relationship)
it's just a syntax thing
there's a list of elements that are void
they are the ones that never have an end tag
that's all there is to it
so you are not defining them as "void" in the XML syntax?
"void" is a text/html syntax feature, it has no equivalent in XML
it's similar to optional tags
or RCDATA elements
hahaha
http://i.imgur.com/Zdk4B.jpg
Now that's nifty
Hixie: why messageerror and not just error?

Hixie: I guess rather than getting hung up on the word "void", I am more interested in finding a way to describe what the common characteristic of this particular set of elements is in the abstract language, rather than in any particular syntax
zcorpan: anne asked for it, see about an hour ago in the irc logs
zcorpan: i'd rather have error, so if you convince him to change his mind, i'll change it :-)
MikeSmith: the concept of "void" is a syntax thing, it has nothing to do with the abstract language
annevk: error isn't always about network errors
annevk: what's the benefit of messageerror over error?
MikeSmith: you can probably come up with some characteristic of the abstract language that all the void elements share, but it'll be just a coincidence
MikeSmith: how do you describe elements that have optional tags?

zcorpan: I don't label them with anything. Is your suggestion that it would be an improvement to not have any special label for "elements that are not allowed to have contents under any circumstances"?
MikeSmith: it's similar in concept; i don't suggest which approach is better
zcorpan, I thought we were going to have an event for network errors as well
MikeSmith: but if you're talking about void elements, i think the definition should be accurate
zcorpan, and since I thought that was the case I thought it should be error rather than closeerror
OK
zcorpan, Hixie, so since we now expose this information on close I suppose we can use error after all
zcorpan, Hixie, though having said that, is there a context where error is dispatched more than once?
hmm, maybe applicationCache
script onerror
as in, window.onerror
but that's not an actual event :)
media elements can get error several times if you load() it several times
workers too
or change src
zcorpan, well yeah, but goes for , XMLHttpRequest etc. too
zcorpan, I meant one operation causing it to be dispatched multiple times
forgot how window.onerror worked
sigh. I broke sync XHR semantics
(locally only but still annoying)
should .ogg be video/ogg or audio/ogg ?
No
application/ogg
I think
.ogv is conventially video/ogg
Seems like you need more information than the file extension to make a correct choice
leaves out .ogg from his article
It seems like media is all too confusing and should be served with a mime type like media/theres-no-way-I-made-the-right-choice
Thanks to .ogg existing, you can't even tell whether it's audio or video...
zcorpan: if you could determine MIME types based solely on file extension, there wouldn't be a need for MIME types
Dashiva, that's an inherent problem with container formats that can contain 1 or more streams of multiple formats
jgraham, just omit Content-Type!
media/unknown
unknown/ogg
Lachy: Makes me wonder, what happens if you give a file containing multiple audio streams as input to <audio>?
I believe it will select the first audio stream
since there is no stream selection in the api
notes that Larry took credit on putting MIME into HTTP in his latest blog post
s/on/for/
but UAs might provide some stream selection mechanism
"In a normal standards group, the group would have a discussion, and come to some conclusion, and the editor would follow along with the group consensus."
Kind of like how the group had a discussion and concluded canvas was in scope
Well, that was funny, opened a linked Google Wave and the scripts it uses is making Firefox cry and hang. Good thing I got a stop script at one point.
zcorpan: .ogg should actually be audio/ogg according to some RFC, for legacy reasons mostly
foolip: yeah i've heard that, although i think some conversion tools output ogg videos with .ogg extensions
which kinda makes the rfc out of touch with reality, and we'll probably end up with videos labeled as audio/ogg
which is why browsers will assume <video> when loading audio/ogg content directly
zcorpan / annevk: congratz on 10.50
zcorpan: doesn't matter, serving everything as any "maybe" or "yes" mime type (e.g. .m4v as audio/x-wav) would work
I'm not sure if browsers rejecting e.g. text/plain will actually lead to the right mime type being used
asmodai: thanks
foolip: gif/jpg/ico are in the same situation, but are mostly correctly labeled (i think)
and png
For some definition of mostly
I get warnings about mislabeled images from irfanview regularly
Hixie: yt?
ok, so now Opera has Theora support, too. now if xiph released a thusnelda version of xiphqt, I could write a tutorial without hand-waving about future software
Argh, why would you use script and abspos to simulate fixpos?  Pretty sure everyone supports it.
TabAtkins: 'cept for ie6, yes
miketaylr: Man, seriously?  I always forget what IE6 doesn't support, dammit.  >_<
Lucky me I'm allowed to ignore it.
me too :D
this guy sometimes helps, http://a.deveria.com/caniuse/#feat=css-fixed
Ah, right.  I like that page.
sad that Apple is not using patents just for defense
sad that the BBC is proposing to close down 6Music
OK, that might just be me
But I just found out and am devestated
It wouldn't be until the end of 2011, apparently
That doesn't help much if they do in fact do it
It only means there is a little time to try to stop them
It also means you can spend the next two years listening to it
is confused by the whole thing, like how they propose to make more money abroad whilst simultaneously cancelling their most popular shows abroad like Top Gear
You could even save the two years' output to disk, and play it on loop for the rest of forever
they are cancelling Top Gear?
aaah
since you'll have forgotten about the earlier shows later on
whenever I see it that show is fun
hadn't heard that about Top Gear
I'd heard they were planning to sell the Top Gear magazine, but that's quite different
Philip`: It just means I will spend two years being upset at the stupidity of whoever thinks that UK Commerical radio is an acceptable alternative
Oh maybe I got the wrong idea about Top Gear
I was still in shock by that part of the article
listens to Norwegian radio now and then nowadays
has not listened to much Swedish radio, but it has always been utterly dreadful
oh yes
my HD arrived
time to power down and start over I guess
(I guess I don't have very Swedish taste in music)
Could I file a bug with the W3C validator team asking them that if they find a page using a strict doctype is invalid, that they check it against HTML5 and report it as valid HTML5 if it is?
That would make MediaWiki's switch to HTML5 significantly smoother.
Does anyone know who I could talk to about it?
Is <nav role="navigation"> completely unnecessary or good accessibility practice?
JonathanNeal, completely unnecessary.

"Opera requires that your video file is served as video/ogg for it to play."  Why?
that's not entirely accurate; we also accept application/ogg and audio/ogg and audio/wav etc
but text/plain and text/html etc are rejected
because the spec says so
Oh, feh.
Why does the spec say so?  These aren't script, are there security problems?
Apache seems to serve application/ogg by default for Ogg, or at least a rule in /etc/apache2/magic seems to say so.
Still not sure why this is necessary.
it's just to avoid mislabeled content
Which will fail anyway when you feed it to GStreamer, no?
The server might mislabel, the video player will know for sure whether it can play the file.
Server-set MIME types should be treated as hints of intent, not an actual description of what the content is, because how should the server know that?  But maybe there's a good reason here.
sure, but if we play text/plain videos, then we need to sniff for video for text/plain if we want to be able to play mislabeled videos when loaded directly
plus, we want to reject video/mp4 if we can't play mpeg-4
Well, I assume you already do other types of sniffing there anyway, so why not?
so it's not much effort to also reject text/plain
because we don't know what gstreamer supports so we don't know what to sniff for
doesn't get what the benefit is to users or authors that outweighs the annoyance of authors potentially having to configure their servers.
So let GStreamer sniff.  It presumably returns an error graciously if it can't play it, right?
GStreamer is the only part of the system that knows for sure what can be played.
Once you've already received the HTTP headers, you've received the start of the content too, so just feed that to GStreamer and that will be a lot more reliable than guessing based on header.
Of course, it makes sense to sniff based on MIME type in the HTML, because that way you can avoid unnecessary requests.
zcorpan, you should mention that old browsers may return "no" from canPlayType().  Your examples should be updated to reflect that too.
AryehGregor: old video-supporting browsers return bogus results for canPlayType anyway, iirc
